title: Zsigmondy's theorem
summary: In number theory, Zsigmondy's theorem, named after Karl Zsigmondy, states that if a > b > 0 {\displaystyle a>b>0} are coprime integers, then for any integer n ≥ 1 {\displaystyle n\geq 1} , there is a prime number p (called a primitive prime divisor) that divides a n − b n {\displaystyle a^{n}-b^{n}} and does not divide a k − b k {\displaystyle a^{k}-b^{k}} for any positive integer k < n {\displaystyle k<n} , with the following exceptions:
